SourceString: The reek of mildew clings to the waterlogged ash in the hearth. The remnants of a meal left to moulder.

Tecmessa, your dear and faithful sister. Love and greetings, to Chrysanthe.

I have waited for your return as long as I could, hoping that you would return from your journey unscathed. But the Ichthians draw closer every day, and I'm an old woman. Though I would gladly abandon our home, I can't well defend it with pots and pans. 

I write in hope that you may yet return and find this note and join me in the enclave under the militia's protection.

May Zeus, lord of wanderers, bring you safely home.
The following is inscribed in the stone:\r\n\"THE STONE MENAGERIE OF THE HONORABLE QUEEN ERANA \r\n\'WHAT ONCE LIVED, NOW WAITS ETERNALLY FOR ME\'\"
Ichthians reject the gods of Olympos, so this blood-soaked stone must serve some other purpose. You shudder to think what.

The old tales tell of a pathway used by the gods themselves to travel mortal realms in times long past.

Some speculate that these shrines were once the entryways to that celestial highway, alike to the island where clever Odysseus made his berth to journey to the underworld.

The story of brave Aristomenes, who stood undaunted against the Ichthians with his warlike companions describes the hero moving with godlike speed across the land. Perhaps this shrine holds the key.

But the time of gods and heroes is fading. Only monsters remain. This shrine's secrets, I fear, are lost forever.

The following is written with a shaky hand:

"The poet says 'time is the healer of all unnecessary evils,' but he's a liar.

You were half of me, the half that commanded my heart to beat and my lungs to breathe.

What need is there for the goddess of Retribution? Nemesis herself could not dream a more terrible punishment than grief."

Someone has crossed out STOLOS'S FARM and scrawled ENCLAVE in its place - NORTHEAST

GRAVEYARD - NORTHWEST

GLAUKOS'S SHRINE - SOUTHWEST

Someone has crossed out STOLOS'S FARM and scrawled ENCLAVE in its place - NORTH

GRAVEYARD - NORTHWEST

PYRGOS VILLAGE - SOUTHEAST

GLAUKOS'S SHRINE - WEST

GLAUKOS'S SHRINE - WEST

GLAUKOS'S SHRINE - NORTHWEST

CHARON'S POINT - WEST

LOOKOUT'S VANTAGE - SOUTHEAST

VINEYARD - NORTHEAST

Someone has crossed out STOLOS'S FARM and scrawled ENCLAVE in its place - SOUTH

GRAVEYARD - SOUTHWEST

An early entry reads:

"Can't wait till the boys see what I've found. A real naiad lily. We're going to be rich. We're going to get away from this gods-forsaken coast."

A few entries after:

"The lily, the lily. It's all I can think about. The boys think I've gone soft in the brain, that I swallowed too much floodwater. They can't see it. Nothing else compares. Wine, women, glory. I can't believe those things ever brought me pleasure."

The next entry:

"Oh gods, all is meaningless. The lily mocks me with its beauty. I can't be happy with it, and I can't live without it."

The final entry:

"The sea below calls to me. I must be free."

Onetas, what\'s taking you so long? You\'ve been down in the farmlands for weeks, and you haven\'t accomplished shit. With the farmers and fish-men fighting each other, you and your warriors should already have taken over the whole area. Prove how strong the Bronze Lions are! Or are you still just a pathetic little cub? Your next report better be more impressive or I\'m coming down there myself to show them how sharp a real lion\'s claws are.

Much of the scroll has been destroyed by ichthian scratchings. Only a few sentences are legible...

"...the very first day of his divine existence, the first act of Hermes was to find and slay a turtle, crafting the very first lyre from its strong shell. 

Then, new-born Hermes stole fifty sacred cattle belonging to Apollo of the silver bow, reversing their hooves so they could not be tracked, desiring to sacrifice their rich meat to the gods. He hoped to catch the attention of Olympos and gain the respect..."

The inscription shines brightly with an inner light, the words crisp and clear:

"You who desire the blessing of Hermes,

God of travellers, messengers, cunning and trade,

Bring here the beast from which Hermes crafted the first lyre,

And sacrifice it before the altar, spilling its blood on this ground."

“…after the catastrophe with Skylla, Glaukos was guilt-stricken, and tried to save the shipwrecked, drowning sailors. He gave them gills so he could guide them to a new, peaceful life underwater. But the transformed sailors were angry and rejected Glaukos, preferring to mate with sea monsters until they became nothing more than monsters themselves…”
High-pitched screeching emanates from the blackness within. It\'s too tight for a human to squeeze through.
A thick, animal scent wafts from the darkness. It\'s too tight for a human to squeeze through.
The flapping of leathery wings echoes in the dark. It\'s too tight for a human to squeeze through.

The inscription is crumbling and faded, only some of the words visible:

"You who ------ the ble-sing of -----s,

--- -- tra---lers, ---sengers, c------ and trade,

----- here the ----- from whi-h H----- crafted t-- first ----,

And -------ce it --fore the ---ar, spill--- its ----- on this gr--nd."

In a bygone age, the wealthy Queen Erana ruled over a peaceful kingdom. When a sea monster attacked, she used her gold to trade for the fabled severed head of a Gorgon. The head was dead, but the vile snakes that slithered in place of hair lived on. The head retained a dark power, turning any who gazed into its decaying eyes to stone. Queen Erana confronted the giant sea monster, petrifying it and saving her kingdom.

But Queen Erana grew drunk on the power the head gave her. She began petrifying all sorts of magical creatures, turning them into statues to add to her stone menagerie. Then, one day, Queen Erana vanished. 

Some claimed that one of the creatures she petrified somehow got the better of her, and others claimed that the Gorgon head decayed into mush, the hair-like snakes slithering free and devouring her. Only the gods know the truth.

This crumpled page is covered with several abandoned attempts to begin a letter... 

“Dear Issa, 
I know I haven’t been the easiest man to get along with. It’s been hard for me to 

Dear Issa, 
You’re a woman, and I’m a man, I 

Dear Issa, 
Working to feed the refugees with you has made me realize what a kind woman you 

Dear Issa, 
After losing Nysa, I never thought that I’d  
 
Dear Issa...”

An account of how the Fates foretold the fall of the Titan Kronos:\r\n\r\n\"So Kronos devoured his children. But his wife, Rhea, hid the youngest, Zeus, and gave Kronos a rock in his place. And Zeus was hidden away until he grew old and powerful enough to overthrow Kronos…\"
God of sea and sailors, the once-mortal Glaukos stands watch over travellers approaching Pyrgos village.

Among the sea-god\'s gifts is the gift of prophecy. To Herakles he prophesied deification; to Menelaus he told of Agamemnon\'s death.\r\n\r\nTo his oracle, Glaukos has given a share of his foresight. Her riddles are often difficult to understand, but they contain within them glimpses of the future.
\"Beneath this monument, an empty grave / The sea alone knows where I am buried.\"
\"For one taken young, but remembered forever. We are the unfortunate ones, who survive.\"
The wolf howls mournfully at the sky, tendons straining in its throat.
Inside the eagle\'s broken neck stump the stone has the texture of flesh.
The raging bull looks to have been frozen mid-charge.
Her wide eyes stare straight ahead.
These overflowing sacks of barley are marked with the occasional smear of blood.
A note atop the untouched, rotting food reads: \"Congratulations on your marriage! Enjoy the food!\"
\"Ianeira, it\'s me. I can\'t keep waiting, there are too many of them. I\'m going to try to make it to town. I hope you\'re safe. I love you.\"
This abandoned cart is loaded up with emergency supplies and personal belongings.
This hay is damp and rotting, rendered useless for feeding livestock.

"Barley - 71 sacks
Lentils - 22 sacks
Olives (in brine) - 18 jars 
Olive Oil - 86 full amphorae (thank the gods)
Dried Figs - Only one box left. Save for feast day?
Salted Fish - Storeroom half full"
\"...Perse, Ianeira, Kaenas, Iphitos, Bardas, Isandros, Issa (left for enclave, arrived?), Thon, Alastor, Boros…\"

“There once was a cute little bird,
Who knew secrets nobody had heard,
She tried to fly away,
She flapped the whole day,
i want to go home”

\"He was right, Lord Pan\'s embrace is so warm. I spend my days filling my belly with steamed trout and sugared apples. At night I lie on supple grass and walk with you in endless pastures. Come join me in the daylight, everything can be like it was.\"
“...nomios agreus agrotas phorbas sinoeis skoleitas halliplanktos…”
“…in a green, green field surrounded by forest. He’s standing there. Giver of Pasture! The Horned One!…”
“I hear Syrinx weeping every time he plays…”
…every second day at sundown, offer sweet wine to the waves as a libation to blue-skinned Glaukos…

Akheloios, the river god, courted the lovely Deianeira in three forms: a charging bull, a coiled serpent, and a bull-faced man–until Herakles challenged the god for Deianeira’s hand. \r\n\r\nHerakles defeated Akheloios, and ever after Herakles delighted in burning the symbols of his enemy to ash.
Only the ichthians know what dark rites they participate in. But the freshly-sharpened blades and unholy inscriptions don\'t bode well…
\"...Great Zeus rendered Ploutos, god of wealth, blind, so he\'s without prejudice, and lame, to teach mortals patience…\"

It's been two days now since the dam broke, the ichthians swarmed in, and everything turned to shit. Seems to me that it's an event worthy of recording. Maybe one day my children--if the gods bless us with any after the wedding--can read it and wonder at the wild life of their mother.

Those of us who couldn't make it back to Pyrgos are holed up on Stolos's farm. Stolos is being his typical insufferable self and refusing to share food, so Dorian and I are spending the day fishing for everyone. It's risky, but people will starve before long. Hopefully we'll have a good haul, and can avoid the ichthians on the way back.

Dorian just spotted sails on the horizon, coming from the north. Could it be traders? Maybe they've got some food stores we can trade for…

Day 1: Whether it’s a “divine” plant or not, I’m sure I can get moly root to grow for the harvest festival. Timandra’s crocuses won’t win first place this time! 

Day 5: It’s dying! Maybe I watered it too much? Or too little? 

Day 7: Philon helped me repot the moly root, he apparently has some expertise. Will see if there are any improvements but I’m doubtful.

Day 8: I woke up and the moly root was in full bloom! I can’t wait to see Timandra’s face when I win the competition!

Day 9: The Pyrgos dam just broke, and they’re saying that ichthians have been seen nearby! I hope the militia deals with it before any harm comes to my garden.
Primitive words and drawings are scrawled in blood. The words are difficult to make sense of, but the drawings show smoke, crossed swords and arrows pointing to the enclave.
“…here lies the Lion of the West, his will unbroken…”
A clutch of large turtle eggs, warm to the touch.
A sharp outcropping of stone, with recent bloodstains as if someone cut themselves on it…
This rocky protrusion is very sharp and seems easy to accidentally cut yourself on.
\"The initial batches showed shapeshifting properties — unexpected, but there might be a different application...\"
\"The brew is nearing its completion. I just need to find Fegrend\'s Scroll of Spider-Handling to learn how to gather that last needed ingredient.\"
\"...softly tickling its bulbous behind encourages the overly dramatically dubbed \"exploding spider\" to emit their valuable excretion peacefully.\"
\"Intricate webbings span the entirety of the wall. This is truly great craftsmanship.\"
This ancient, faded scroll contains a few legible phrases:\r\n\r\n“...remain vigilant since we lost the north… Skylla must not be allowed south… the Queen’s power will preserve us until the threat…”
\"King Helenos, builder of ships and father of our great queen.\"
This aged and crumbling note still has a few legible words:\r\n\r\n\"...watch the tower door for intruders! The Queen\'s enemies are...\"
These hasty scrawlings are faded by time:\r\n\r\n\"...send reinforcements! Skylla, she...\"

Klotho, I ask you to watch over the birth.

Lachesis, I ask that you ensure the child lives a good life.

Atropos, I ask that the end comes late, and comes gently.
Gazemos, riches surely await us! You can outsmart the turtle! Just keep trying!
